topic: Socio Religious Reform Movement, Organisations and Personalities
subtopic: Lower Caste Movements in Colonial India

flashcards.back: Jyotirao Phule, 1873 Maharashtra (UPSC 2016)
Social justice, education for lower castes and women
Mailis, Telis, Kunbis
Brahmanical Tyranny: Exploitation through religion
Rejected Lord Rama, promoted Rajah Bali
Abolition of caste, equality, human dignity
Girls' school with Jyotirao, widow remarriage movement, widow shelter 1854
Jyotirao Phule: Political Engagement 1876
Impact: Social justice, inclusivity, Western India
Sree Narayana Guru (1854-1928), Kerala, 1903
Untouchability, denied education, temple entry in Kerala
Installed Sivalinga from Neyyar River at Aruvippuram - challenged caste-based practices
1889: Aruvippuram Kshetra Yogam
1903: Registered under Indian Companies Act with Guru as permanent chairman, Kumaran Asan as general secretary
Advocated religious equality, caste abolition, human unity
'One religion, one caste, one god for mankind' - Criticised Congress and Gandhi for not addressing caste discrimination
'No dividing walls of caste or race, live in brotherhood'
Promoted social mobility for Ezhavas in education, government jobs, temple entry, political representation.
Key role in social justice coalitions for backward castes in Kerala
Led to structural changes in Kerala's power dynamics, challenging caste-based discrimination, fostering unity for social justice
Dr. T.M. Nair, P. Tyagaraja Chetti, C.N. Mudaliar - Indian Liberation Federation (SILF) 1916, Madras
Challenge Brahmin dominance in government service, education, politics
Led to reservations for various communities through government orders. First non-Brahmin political organisation in South India
Represented non-Brahmin interests and social justice
1937-1944: Became President, spearheaded anti-Brahmanism and social reform
Hinduism, Laws of Manu, Puranas as inhumane
Removed caste name-boards from hotels, desecrated Hindu idols, cut sacred threads worn by Brahmins, advocated end of Brahmanical Hinduism
'Some things cannot be mended, only ended'
1944: Dravida Kazhagam (Dravidian Federation). 1949: Became DMK under C.N. Annadurai, continuing Periyar's agenda
C.V. Raman Pillai, K. Rama Krishna Pillai, M. Padmanabha Pillai, 1891 Kerala
Emerged in response to Brahmin dominance in Kerala
C.V. Raman Pillai: Established Nair Memorial to challenge Brahminical authority. M.
Padmanabha Pillai: Founded Nair Service Society (NSS) to uplift Nair community, ensure rights and social mobility
Aimed at securing social equality for non-Brahmin communities, particularly Nairs, against Brahminical hegemony
E.V. Ramaswami Naicker (Periyar), 1925, Tamil Nadu
Reject Brahminical customs, challenge caste hierarchy, promote rationalism
Criticised Brahmanism as agents of oppression. Advocated alternative wedding ceremonies, women's liberation.
Mobilised marginalised communities against caste injustice
Kudi (1910)
Reshaped social fabric in Tamil Nadu. Formed Justice Party. Pushed for egalitarianism and social justice
Shanans, untouchable caste of agricultural labourers in Tamil Nadu, 1910
By 19th century became prosperous mercantile class, adopted title 'Nadars' to claim Kshatriya status
Counter social prejudice, advance welfare for Nadar community
Nadar Mahajana Sangam established 1910
B.R. Ambedkar, 1924, Maharashtra
Elevate Mahar community (untouchables) in Maharashtra
Access to public places, temple entry, abolition of Mahar Watan, separate representation in legislative council
Initiated by Depressed Classes Institution (Marathi fortnightly)
Formed to advocate for untouchables' rights
Mahatma Gandhi, Madan Mohan Malviya, Jamnalal Bajaj, 1917 onwards
Abolish untouchability, elevate social status of Dalits
Passed resolution advocating abolition of untouchability, urged elimination of customary-imposed disabilities on Dalits
Formation within Congress, led by Madan Mohan Malviya and Jamnalal Bajaj
Established by Gandhi to further the cause
Published by Mahatma Gandhi
1897 onwards, Midnapore, Bengal
Establishment of Jati Nirdharsan Sabha 1897, Mahishya Samiti 1901 - Initial steps toward evolution of Kaivartas' identity
forming cohesive identity of Mahishyas
1924, Vaikom, Northern Travancore
K.P. Kesava
Challenge denial of untouchables access to temples and public roads
National attention, Jathas (processions) from Punjab and Madurai. Mahatma Gandhi visited Kerala to show solidarity
Vaikom Satyagraha 1924: K.P. Kesava. Objective: Demand opening of Hindu temples and public roads to untouchables.
Support: Reinforced by Jathas from Punjab and Madurai. Gandhi visited Kerala
Leaders: K. Kelappan and poet Subramaniyam Tirumambu ('singing sword of Kerala').
Event: 16 volunteers led by Tirumambu marched to Guruvayur to challenge temple entry restrictions
P. Krishna Pillai, A.K. Gopalan
Maharaja of Travancore issued proclamation allowing all Hindu castes access to government-controlled temples
Leader: C. Rajagopalachari. Expansion: Madras administration followed suit, expanding movement's influence across southern India
Founded Anarya Dosh Parihar Samaj, published 'Vital Vidhwansak' to protest against Brahmanism
Tamil Nadu: Promoted Siddha medicine, Buddhist conversion, founded Dalit Mahajan Sabha
Lower-caste members consecrated Shiva idol in temple, challenging caste restrictions. Sri Narayana Guru played key role
Anti-Brahmin movement in Mysore, challenging prevailing social hierarchy.
B'Byanna was Sangha's first president, Maharaja of Mysore, Krishnaraja Wodeyar IV and Diwan V.P.
Madhava Rao were association's patron and vice-patron

mcq.question: Who founded Satyashodhak Samaj and when?
mcq.explanation: Jyotirao Phule founded Satyashodhak Samaj in 1873 Maharashtra (UPSC 2016).

mcq.question: Satyashodhak Samaj rejected which deity?
mcq.explanation: Satyashodhak Samaj rejected Lord Rama and promoted Rajah Bali.

mcq.question: When did Sree Narayana Guru install Sivalinga at Aruvippuram?
mcq.explanation: 1888: Sree Narayana Guru installed Sivalinga from Neyyar River at Aruvippuram, challenging caste-based practices.

mcq.question: When was SNDP registered?
mcq.explanation: 1903: SNDP Yogam registered under Indian Companies Act with Guru as permanent chairman, Kumaran Asan as secretary.

mcq.question: SNDP famous slogan?
options: 'Some things cannot be mended, only ended'
'One religion, one caste, one god for mankind'
mcq.explanation: SNDP's famous slogan: 'One religion, one caste, one god for mankind' - criticized Congress and Gandhi.

mcq.question: Who founded Justice Movement (1916)?
options: Dr. T.M. Nair, P. Tyagaraja Chetti, C.N. Mudaliar
mcq.explanation: Dr. T.M. Nair, P. Tyagaraja Chetti, C.N. Mudaliar founded Indian Liberation Federation (SILF) in 1916, Madras.

mcq.question: When did Periyar lead Justice Party?
mcq.explanation: Periyar's leadership 1937-1944: Became President, spearheaded anti-Brahmanism and social reform.

mcq.question: Periyar's motto?
options: 'Some things cannot be mended, only ended'
mcq.explanation: Periyar's motto: 'Some things cannot be mended, only ended.'

mcq.question: When did Justice Party become Dravida Kazhagam?
mcq.explanation: 1944: Dravida Kazhagam (Dravidian Federation). 1949: Became DMK under C.N. Annadurai.

mcq.question: Who founded Self-Respect Movement (1925)?
mcq.explanation: E.V. Ramaswami Naicker (Periyar) founded Self-Respect Movement in 1925, Tamil Nadu.

mcq.question: Who founded Depressed Classes (Mahars) Movement?
mcq.explanation: B.R. Ambedkar founded Depressed Classes (Mahars) Movement in 1924, Maharashtra.

mcq.question: When was Congress' first resolution on untouchability?
mcq.explanation: 1917: Congress passed resolution advocating abolition of untouchability.

mcq.question: When was Vaikom Satyagraha?
mcq.explanation: Vaikom Satyagraha was in 1924, led by K.P. Kesava in Northern Travancore.

mcq.question: Who led Guruvayur Satyagraha (1931)?
mcq.explanation: Guruvayur Satyagraha 1931: K. Kelappan and poet Subramaniyam Tirumambu led 16 volunteers.

mcq.question: When did Travancore allow temple access to all Hindu castes?
mcq.explanation: 1936: Maharaja of Travancore issued proclamation allowing all Hindu castes access to government-controlled temples.

comprehensive.question: Compare regional lower caste movements (Maharashtra - Satyashodhak Samaj, Kerala - SNDP/Nair, Tamil Nadu - Justice/Self-Respect, Bengal - Kaivartas) analyzing their distinct strategies, leadership, and impact on challenging Brahminical hegemony in their respective contexts.
comprehensive.answer: Maharashtra - Satyashodhak Samaj (1873): Founder: Jyotirao Phule. Leadership: Mailis, Telis, Kunbis (OBC communities). Objective: Social justice, education for lower castes and women.
